subject: Re: on screen representation of senior quikscript
msgSnippet: Yes Jerome is a fine font and does make many of the senior connections possible. But I think you are right: I ll look into a purely font based solution
messageBody:
Yes Jerome is a fine font and does make many of the "senior"
connections possible. But I think you are right: I'll look into a
purely font based solution first. I hesitated only because that path
seems to require a system like the Unicode combining diacritical marks
(which are hardly charming) as well as the addition of number of
variations for many letters (also a tad gross) and finally because
font editing is hardly my strong point.
But if no one has done this, I may as well give it a whirl. I'm
with child to start reading texts in the "senior" format. Which brings
me to my next issue: I don't suppose anyone has put together a
"junior" to "senior" parser yet? I saw a proposal for this elsewhere
in this group but I wonder if any steps have been taken yet.

-Tony


--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, pgabhart <pgabhart@...> wrote:
>
> Tony:
>
> The font Jerome, which was the first QS font, had the capability of
> joining letters together and permitted the use of half-letters. In
> actual use, however, it had some problems, though, and the fonts that
> came after it were focused more on junior QS. A new attempt at a
senior
> QS font would be welcome and certainly interesting. I, for one, would
> consider using it if you could get it to work well. It would permit
the
> computer to reproduce the cursive character of QS which I find so
> interesting.
>
> This is not to say that an artistic, well-designed junior QS font is
not
> needed. Paul Tremblay is working on just such a new junior font now
> that will deal with some of the issues the existing junior fonts have
> had. I have great hopes for it.
>
> Thanks for your interest, and I would be happy to assist you in any way
> I can if you decide to work on such a project.
>
> Paige
>
> othermale wrote:
> >
> > Hi All,
> >
> > I wonder, does anyone know of an attempt to represent _senior_
> > quikscript typographically (ie enterable and viewable on a computer)?
> > I suppose this would be quite a bit more than just a font (eg the
> > challenge of joining the letter "roar"(aka "roe") and half letter
> > "zoo" in the abbreviation for Mrs. or the joining of "sis"("see") with
> > "pipe"("pea") ). I was toying with the notion of building an app for
> > this but if this or something better has already been done by
someone...
> >
> > cheers,
> > -Tony
> >
> >
>
